39632607.review:
I have the pro version of the game here and have been using it for around 2 years. 

No regrets at all - if you are a coaster enthusiast this is a must-have. 

Note: This is not a "game" but rather a simulator or even an almost cad-like program. It has a steep learning curve. There are many advanced features built-in that can take your rides to the next level but like other software, this takes time to learn. 

Also, unlike Planet Coaster, in order to make custom scenery, you must either create it with supports or learn to use an external CAD program (Sketchup, Blender, Fusion 360, Solidworks, etc.) 

Once you get to know the software the possibilities are endless. I have created coaster upon coaster, and there is an entire community around this, with contests and guides and many others. All in all one of the best purchases I have ever made.

This review applies only to the VR experience riding the coasters, not the Editor/Design (which I understand is fairly difficult and complex, and probably also warrants a positive review).

Riding the provided coasters and the ones available for free on Steam Workshop is the best VR coaster experience I've found.  There are plenty of other coaster riding videos or small experiences that are adequate, but this one really simulates the realism of roller coasters, to the point where, even though you're not moving, you can feel your stomach drop as you crest the inital summit of a ride. 33649495.review:
Gleich vorneweg:
Wem das Achterbahn-bauen in Rollercoaster Tycoon schon auf die Säcke ging und es zu schwer fand, ist hier definitiv falsch!

No Limits 2 ist der Nachfolger der Achterbahn-Simulation No Limits, welche unter Coaster-Fans einen sehr guten Ruf beanspruchen konnte, nicht zuletzt wegen dem extrem hohen Realismusgrad, dem grenzenlosen Editor sowie einem unglaublich gut nachempfundenen "mittendrin"-Gefühl. Dass die Grafik dabei, nett gesagt, zweckmäßig war, tat dem Spiel keinen Abbruch.
In etwas erweiterter Form wurde es sogar von realen Firmen verwendet, um erste Layouts geplanter Achterbahnen zu erstellen, und diese dann dem Kunden als digitale Vorschau mit Möglichkeit, ein erstes Bild zu bekommen, zu präsentieren.

NL2 verändert das ganze Spielgeschehen nicht unbedingt, sondern erweitert es um sehr sinnvolle Features, welche ich, zusätzlich zu weiteren Unterschieden zu NL, später noch mal beleuchten möchte.

NL2 ist an sich ein Achterbahn-Baukasten. Im Editor stehen verschiedene Achterbahn-Typen bereit, darunter Klassiker von Schwarzkopf, Maurer Söhne, Gerstlauer, Intamin, B&M... also quasi all das, was unter Coastergeeks bereits bekannt ist.
Wer jetzt denkt, man klickt sich durch vorgefertigtes Zeug, irrt sich.
Denn JEDE einzelne Schiene der Kreation muss eingenhändig gelegt und angepasst werden.
Hier stehen unzählige Möglichkeiten zur Wahl. Neben der normalen Ausrichtung nach links oder Rechts, oben oder unten, kann die Schiene noch in sich gedreht werden (->Steilkurve z.B.), das ganze ohne Begrenzung, wer also exakt 176,24° biegen will, kann das tun!
Natürlich gibt´s auch einige Elemente vorgefertigt, ansonsten liegt alles in der Hand des Spielers!
Neben Ausrichtung und Neigung gilt es auch die Länge oder Art (normale Schiene, Bremse, Lift...) zu bestimmen.

Der Editor selbst ist staubtrocken wie eine Blaupause, setzt aber zum Glück nicht voraus, dass man Architektur studiert hat, wobei ein fundiertes Fachwissen über Begriffe wie "Vertex", "Helix", "Launch", "G-Kräfte" sehr vorteilhaft ist.
Absolute Neulinge werden also erstmal in die Röhre schauen bzw. sich über kleine runde Strecken ohne viel Tamtam freuen...

Neu hinzugekommen sind dabei sowohl optische als auch spielerische Elemente.
Fortan ist es möglich, die "Abnutzung" der Strecke einzustellen. Zudem können nun via Scrips Events ausgelöst werden, um z.B. eine Lichtshow zu starten, einen Soundeffekt zu triggern, eine Tür zu öffnen...

Für einen Coaster-Fan also DAS Grundpaket zum erstellen seiner Träume!

Trotz allem ist gerade der Editor extrem komplex und schwer zu bedienen und basiert größtenteils auf mathematischen Eingaben und Scripts.
Das Grundgerüst der Strecke ist noch relativ einfach zu erstellen, das Feintuning bezüglich Neigungen, Radien, Steigungen oder simple Dinge wie die Verzögerung der Bremsen oder Geschwindigkeiten von Transportelementen hingegen wird nahezu vollständig mit Dezimalen eingestellt.


Ebenso kann man nun auch in die Rolle eines Ride-OP schlüfen, sprich die Abfertigung vornehmen, Züge auf die Reise schicken, aber auch die neuen Abstellgleise bedienen. Im Full-Manual-Modus sogar jede einzelne Bremse und Antriebsmöglichkeit selbst steuern.
Auch ist es möglich, durch die vom Spieler erstellte Attraktion zu laufen, oder, wenn sich eine weitere Attraktion auf derselbe Karte befindet, zu dieser zu wechseln.
Dass man jeden Sitz des Coasters auch besetzen und mitfahren kann, ist glaube ich selbstverständlich, wobei eine VR-Unterstützung noch etwas mehr Realismus verleiht (Vorsicht: Motion Sickness an der Tagesordnung!)

Ist die Kreation dann fertig, steht die erste Testfahrt an. Vermutlich werden sich zu Beginn viele Fehler aufzeigen, wie ungerade Geraden, harte, ruckelige Fahrtverläufe (-> Schläge), zu enge Radien uvm.. Das treibt die G-Werte natürlich in ungesunde Bereiche, also steht wieder verbessern, ausprobieren, verbessern, ausprobieren auf dem Plan, bis es endlich "glatt" läuft.

Um mit NL2 Spaß zu haben, muss man also einfach ein Freund dieser Art sein, ansonsten ist hier schnell Ende im Gelände.

Du magst "Kingda Ka", "Schwur des Kärnan", "Desert Race"....? Dann kannst du sie hier nachbauen!
Und wer keinen Bock auf bauen hat, greift einfach auf bestehendes Material zurück, die die Community im Workshop oder auf verschiedenen Seiten erschaffen hat.
Manch einer lässt sich inspirieren und hat plötzlich wieder ein neues Projekt am Start...

Grafisch wurde das Spiel verbessert und wirkt nun noch schöner. Subtile Details wie bewegende Räder, Bremsen uvw. tragen dazu bei, dass NL2 die wohl schönste und realistischste Simulation am Markt ist.
Fehlende Fahrgäste sind da wirklich zu verschmerzen.
Der Sound ist ebenfalls für dieses Spiel gut gelungen, wobei es nicht wirklich viele Geräusche gibt. Die, die es gibt, sind aber realistisch und gut eingebunden.

Da NL2 aber sehr viele physikalische Prozesse in Echtzeit errechnet, ist es von Vorteil, einen leistungsstarken PC zu haben. Ein mit Scripts und Objekten übersäter Coaster zieht derart viel Leistung, dass die Framerate fast zum erliegen kommt.
Selbst 4GB Grafikspeicher und 16GB RAM lassen das Spiel, zumindest bei mir, kurzzeitig ruckelig laufen, fährt man alle Optionen voll aus.

Man muss wirklich ein Fan dieser Art Spiel/Programm sein, um Freude zu haben. Wer hier ein Spiel sucht, in dem er eigene Achterbahnen in einigen Minuten erstellen kann, ist bei NL2 absolut an der Falschen Adresse, für diese Zielgruppe gibt es bessere Alternativen, sei es das alte Rollercoaster Tycoon 3, Planet Coaster oder der uralte Disney-Achterbahn-Designer.
Wer hingegen eine Herausforderung sucht und kein Problem damit hat, zu Beginn Tutorials zu verschlingen und Wissen zu erlernen, kann bei NL2 seine Kreationen perfekt umsetzen!

Wer also auf der Suche nach einer anspruchsvollen UND realistischen Simulation zugleich ist, ist hier richtig aufgehoben!

31760213.review:
[h1]Realistic roller coasters, perfect for the ultimate VR experience![/h1]

I've been a VR player and Vive owner since October 2016, and NoLimits 2 is the only roller coaster game I keep coming back to for riding coasters.  It runs pretty well on less-than-optimal hardware (AMD Phenom II X4 955, no issues at all), and it even got a multi-core optimization update recently.  It's one of the few roller coaster simulators on Steam to take the realistic approach.

The building tools are kind of dated and confusing.  I can't stress that enough.  It's not a good experience making coasters for this simulator.  It definitely takes tutorials and research to figure out how the park editor works.  There isn't a lot of documentation for this, either, that I could find.  Granted, I primarily got the app for riding coasters, not making them, so i gave up pretty quickly on building anything.  There is Workshop support, so you'll find a lot of coasters to ride.

The VR controls are also non-existent.  You have to use the mouse and keyboard to navigate every bit of the game, from menu UIs to walking around parks.

NoLimits 2 is worth the $40 if you have a Vive or Oculus or similar OSVR headset and want to experience realistic coaster rides.  I go into it every few weeks for 20-30 minutes at a time.  I also use it as a demo experience for my friends to try out roomscale VR.

29374280.review:
Honestly I'm upset with anyone who dares to give this masterpiece of a rollercoaster editing program a negative review. I've read most of them and it seems that they're complaining about either of these two things:

- The VR triggers motion sickness
- The editor is very complex and thus has a steep learning curve.

I wouldn't have any issues with these two complaints, had they been properly built and supported with valid reasoning. However, that's not the case. Not at all.

Of course the VR will trigger motion sickness for some people, because this is a rollercoaster simulator. If you have a weak stomach in terms of consistent movements, don't buy this game. This should have been obvious before you bought the game in the first place.

Listen, if you're in doubt whether to buy this game or not, consider that this is a complex rollercoaster simulator that professional coaster designers use. Most of the community is very passionate about rollercoasters and standards are high. Don't let that scare you off though, instead watch a bunch of tutorials online if you find the editor to be too difficult. You can even choose which path you want to take. You can go with hand building, or math building. I personally could never really find myself within hand building, so i picked math building, which suits me so much better. 

This is a game with a steep learning curve, but with an amazing reward factor. When you've built your rollercoaster and you look at the finished product, you'll certainly be satisfied. No other rollercoaster simulator game can compare to this one when it comes to actively building rides and enjoying the beautiful graphics.

24767433.review:
NL2 is possibly, no, DEFINITELY the best roller coaster simulator out there. The physics are top notch, the graphics are clean and sleek, and to top it all off the sound quality is brilliant. NL2 provides the opportunity to not only ride premade coasters made by the developers themselves, it allows you to build your own creations that can come from the deepest parts of your imagination. It could be a realistic B&M Hyper coaster with huge airtime hills, a Gerstlauer Infinity Coaster with 10 or more inversions, or even a sky coaster that dives towards earth killing everyone on board with 30g's of lateral g-forces with a speed of 500mph. This editor also provides the opportunity for the community to upload their creations to the Steam Workshop, which you can download and ride yourself, which provides, in theory, infinite content. The editor is also very intuitive and pretty easy to get the hang of, however hard to master. 

Overall the game is worth every penny, and if you want to support the developers in the constant updates, you can buy a £80 version, which allows many different features not available in the standard version. Big ups to the developrs for their amazing technological achievement, this simulator.

24638543.review:
Probably the most realistic coaster designer I've ever played with. Yes, I said designer - even the physics are realistic. You're able to ride, design / build, and control. And yes, I said control. You're given access to a control panel which lets you control the ride from just "automatic" (which is the AI controlling it, or custom scripts), "blocks", which let's you control segments of the track and release the coaster manually. Or, full manual, which is the hardest of them all. Try to play with 3 coasters at once, it's impossible! Despite people commenting about a "steep learning curve", the editor is quite simple and is quite easy to learn once you've gotten yourself "rolling" (pun intended). I'm not very good yet, but with a bit of practice I suppose I'd be able to design many great coasters.

Note -

You're able to import custom models, sounds, scripts and more, but even the vanilla version is good enough to keep you excited for a good, long set of hours!

Realism: 9.5/10
Customisability: 9.5/10
Overall: 9/10

24384629.review:
This is probably the best roller coaster simulator available on the consumer level. Not only does it just simulate a single coaster, you have many coasters to choose from and in some cases, a whole park is simulated including some non-coaster type of rides (all of which can be ridden.) Also simulated are the fully functioning storage sheds and switch tracks which allow you to move trains into or out of circulation.

If simply riding coasters isn't enough, you can also design, build, and ride your own custom coasters and share them with the community.

All-in-all, this roller-coaster simulator is a must have for anyone interested in designing, building, and/or riding coasters from the comfort of their own home.

24138978.review:
Unfortunately I can only chose between Yes and No.
Therefore...

THIS IS >>ONLY<< A REVIEW OF THE VR COMPONENT

On the basis of me buying it solely as a rollercoaster VR experience (for the Rift CV in my case), I can only say No. I am sure it is a great game otherwise, but if what you want out of it is the same as me, then you have to be certain you have a cast iron stomach. If you do - great, go buy it now!
There's a lot of VR experiences I can handle, but there are also a lot that make me sick if I'm not careful. If you like me need to be a bit careful and can't just take it all, I would not for a second recommend this game. I tried around half of a simple, straightforward, up and down rollercoaster ride (maybe 30 seconds) before I was sweatting profusely and had to tear the headset off to keep from throwing up.
It should be said that I LOVE real world rollercoasters. Up, down, corkscrews, loops, twirls I've done them all and love them in real life... but in VR it would seem I just can't handle it. The high speed turns with no mitigation or control are just too hard.
You can see this as a review of VR rollercoasters in general, from the point of someone who has some problems with VR nausea. Not more than most of my friends who has tried my Oculus though. I don't believe this is a particularly poor implementation, which is why I mention it as a general thing.

Reviewing VR is so very difficult, because there is such an intensely physical and individual component to the experience.
So all I'm saying is Caveat Emptor: VR Buyer Beware.


TLDR; Purely from VR standpoint probably stay away from rollercoasters in general, unless you have no issues with simulation sickness ever.



PS: I feel super bad giving the devs a "No" because of something they can't control. But it's still important info for potential buyers. How we discuss and review VR games are some of the issues we'll have to iron out as VR matures.

20900675.review:
Ich hatte schon sehr viel Spaß in RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 Achterbahnen zu bauen und diese dann zu fahren, aber leider war der Realismusgrad nicht gerade sehr hoch. Mit NoLimits 2 Roller Coaster Simulation wird der Traum jeden Achterbahnfans wahr. Ich persönlich liebe Achterbahnen und deren Technik. Mit diesem "Spiel" kann man seine komplett eigene Achterbahn bauen und fahren. Es ist sogar möglich einen kompletten Park zu bauen, mit Szenerie, sowie Gebäuden und sonstigem Schnickschnack und dann durch diesen Park laufen und sämtliche Achterbahnen besuchen/fahren. Der Editor ist für Neuzugänge echt kompliziert, da war der Editor in NoLimits 1 etwas besser - finde ich zumindest - und übersichtlicher. Aber ich werde es weiter versuchen und den Editor irgendwann verstehen.
Dank des Workshops kann man sich zahlreiche Achterbahnen und Parks herunterladen und spielen. Man muss übrigens mal ein großes Lob an das Supportteam stellen. NoLimits 2 war ursprünglich nicht auf Steam vorhanden. Als diese es auf Steam gebracht haben, konnten alle, die das Spiel von der Webseite gekauft hatten, sich einen kostenlosen Steam-Key zuschicken lassen. Großes Lob mal an dieser Stelle an das Team!

Kommen wir zu einem Fazit. Jeder, der auf Achterbahnen abfährt (hehe) - so wie ich - der ist mit NoLimits 2 mehr als genug bedient. Leute, die mit Achterbahnen nichts anfangen können, ist dieses Spiel natürlich eher nichts. Man muss schon ein gewisses Gefallen an Achterbahnen mitbringen, um wirklich Spaß am Bauen und dem generellen "Spielen" von NoLimits 2 zu haben. Aus persönlicher Sicht habe ich wirklich großen Spaß an NoLimits 2, selbst wenn ich den Editor erst nach 100 Spielstunden verstehen werde. Klare Kaufempfehlung für alle Achterbahnfans!

EDIT: Wow! Ich habe den Editor nun verstanden und es macht sau mäßig Spaß! Ich kann gar nicht mehr aufhören und hab schon angefangen einen Park zu bauen. :D

NoLimits 2 Roller Coaster Simulation is an amazing gem. As the name suggests, it is a roller coaster simulator. But it is not just any roller coaster simulator... it is THE roller coaster simulator. You won't find it any more realistic as this and if you are a fan of roller coasters and super realistic simulation: get this game!

PROs:
- Strong engine with insane physics.
- Many types of roller coasters.
- Editor has anything you want and everything you'll ever need!
- Supports external models, but has many of its own as well.
- Graphics are gorgeous. 
- Many other roller coaster related features such as control panel for the coaster.

CONs:
- Config isn't really in-depth.
- Not always on 60fps and thus some stuttering (and I have a GTX 765M, which pulls a lot).
- This is mostly because of external models or too many coasters in a park.

All in all: this is some serious strong software with great features. Any roller coaster fan who wants to build a good track, as in a real track not that Roller Coaster Tycoon stuff: buy this! You have complete freedom.


EDIT: I wrote this review when having 4 hours. Currently I'm over 20 hours and looking back at this review I'd say nothing has changed. This is just great software! However, I still have to try out the Oculus Rift support.

16494640.review:
Okay, so you are curious about buying this product? If yes, please read this before making your decision.
1. NoLimits 2 is a fantastic piece of software, yeah, software, because, according to the makers, they are targeting realism now and they prever to call it a simulation-program. Keep in mind this ISIN'T RollerCoaster Tycoon or Thrillville.
2. You can't be a sadistic a-hole and watch people die, 2 reasons: there aren't any peeps in the entire simulation, just steel, wood and foliage. The second reason is that you can't crash a coaster, if it hit's the end of the open track it just displays and error stating that the coaster has crashed.
3. If you want to make rollercoasters, of course you do, you have to learn it. It's not that you build gorgeous tracks within the first hour, propably not even after 10 hours of learning. There aren't track-pieces like RollerCoaster Tycoon, it's more CAD-style based, just open air. Actually it's an editor where you can design almost anything inside.
4. You can add buildings, etc. to it, but you have to make them in a program like SketchUp, 3DSMAX, etc. Than you have to export -> import them. As you see, this is not a game for people who don't have patient, this is a quality program which is rather serious. (Although they have an annual April fools joke on the news-website)
If you like building rollercoasters and would invest some time in it to use the same software as some of the professionals use, don't hasitate and buy this gorgeous piece of art!!! If you like rollercoasters to ride them, buy it also, on the market-place and other sources like coastercrazy, nolimits-exchange, etc. you can have an almost unlimited supply of coaster-food. Do you want to build coaster in the simple RollerCoaster Tycoon site and don't want to learn how you make proper creations, yeah, better spend your money on something better. Although this software just deserves to be bought anyways.

15740188.review:
NoLimits 2 is a very relaxing yet thrilling game where you get to ride and build your very own roller coasters! The game itself is lovely with a lot of things to play around with, the biggest one being the editor. This game concentrates more on the ride itself and less on the surroundings while most other games let you build your own parks with pre-built rides this game lets you create your own from scratch or by editing other rides.

[b] Positives: [/b]
+Creative.
+Very pretty.
+Lots of options.
+Very in depth editor with lots and lots of options.
+Easy to understand tutorials in written and video form.
+Audio is incredibly realistic.
+Oculus Rift support.
+Lots of ways to move around (walking, flying ext.)
+Very large areas to build so you can build a lot of rides in one park
+Controls are easy to use.

[b] Negatives: [/b]
-Fly camera is buggy when you fly too fast.
-Weird frame drops in random areas.
-Not that many building options so your parks are going to be just rides.
-Price tag I think can be lowered a bit.

13802388.review:
While I only have a hundred hours of playtime on the Steam version, I've poured many more into the standalone version.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Is this game for me?[/h1]

First off, it's worth knowing that this is not a game, but a simulator. If this interests you, then NoLimits 2 will be a good choice. Your enjoyment of NoLimits 2 is likely bound to how many of these items apply to you:
[list]
    [*]In RollerCoaster Tycoon, you loved the coaster building process the most
    [*]You're a coaster enthusiast
    [*]You enjoy simulation games even if you don't "play" them avidly
    [*]You're the creative type who enjoys a blank canvas or a sandbox with no goals or restrictions
[/list]
Bonus points if these apply to you:
[list]
    [*]You love 3D modeling
    [*]You love programming
[/list]

If 2 of any the above match you, then I'd maybe pick up the game on sale, as you may still enjoy it but perhaps won't sink tons of hours into it. Do note that NoLimits 2 has never gone on sale for anything more than 20%, so don't expect deep discounts on Steam sales.

If 3 match you, then you might enjoy NoLimits 2 as a casual user. If you're the type that just likes to check out the simulation, as well as how insanely creative/detailed people are, there's plenty to download and explore with the Steam workshop and fan websites. You may find yourself tinkering with building your own coasters, but some may lose interest given the vast array of tools at your disposal.

If 4 or more match you, then I would recommend this game at full price.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Comparison with Planet Coaster[/h1]

Planet Coaster is a game. NoLimits 2 is a simulator.

If you enjoy building parks, NoLimits 2 has the ability, but it's not really designed to do this out of the box. You can place some flat rides that come bundled with the game, and you can download more off of the Steam workshop. However, there are no paths, people, or any real tools to build anything efficiently. It's just custom scenery and terrain painting.

Planet Coaster also does a *really* well with its coaster builder. They did a fantastic job of compromising realism and customization with ease of use. If you're just looking for a more realistic RCT3, I would highly recommend Planet Coaster if even for the building coasters alone. You can get fairly close to real life in terms of appearance. Of course, it's still pretty far away from NoLimits 2 in terms of physics, finesse, precision, and overall realism. As a starting point though, it's a nice way to get the basics of coaster design, then transition into something like this.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Comparison with Theme Park Studio[/h1]

Do not buy Theme Park Studio. It is an incomplete Kickstarter early access mess that is lacking in both gameplay and realism. I'd even wager that Planet Coaster has better realism.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Opinion:[/h1]

Naturally, this is the absolute benchmark for accurate roller coasters. The level of intricacy with which someone can design their dream ride is unparalleled by any other software. As with anything this realistic, there is a learning curve that comes with the program if you wish to design your own. However, compared to NoLimits 1, the rate at which new users are becoming proficient truly speaks for how well the new track building system is. Some of the amazing works you'll see on YouTube, the Workshop, and NL fansites were created by people who just picked up the game a couple months ago.

Now, would I recommend this game to those don't plan to build? If you're a roller coaster fanatic, I'd still say yes. With Steam's integration you can download other tracks with absolute breeze. Plus there's other options to further satisfy your hunger for rides: sites like NoLimitsCentral.com and CoasterCrazy.com provide an excellent abundance of things to download to your heart's desire.

If realism isn't your forte, go make that 1000 ft tall mountain racer you've always wanted. If you can build it, the simulation will always run it.

However, the fact that some recreations get within inches of their real-life counterparts just shows the level of detail with which you can sculpt the rails. And for some, having that dead-on accuracy makes each ride feel as though they could be built into real life. You can build your dream ride, watch it go, and truly imagine it existing at your favorite amusement park so long as you could print out blueprints. That feeling is truly awesome and cannot be replaced IMO.

13238680.review:
***Review for NoLimits 2 Professional Edition***
(not all features described may be included in the standard version)

NoLimits 2 by far is the best roller coaster simulator which is currently available and quite probably will be available within the next years. Its focus on realism and customizability stands out as well as the performance on weaker machines (as long as the user-built parks are optimized that is). Although building your very first coaster can be quite a task the editor is easy to control, all buttons are neatly arranged.
You can take in-game screenshots with depth of field and adjustable field of view which can often be close to reality and are able to deceive unaware people (and sometimes even the "pros"). If pictures are too boring for you there is an option for recording videos for which you can enable a motion-blur effect.
Many prefabricated supports are available to help you getting your first coaster done pretty fast. Those can be atomized and customized, or you can build your own supports from scratch with nearly unlimited sizes (from 0.001 m and 2 m) and a few distinct shapes (which can be cloned for easier placement). For wooden coasters it's even possible to auto-generate the supports.
Furthermore, you can choose between many different track connectors and adjust where you want to have friction wheels, friction brake runs or magnetic fins. Custom scenery objects are supported, too. Those inlcude .3ds, .lwo and .dae files and lighting effects are just awesome when used wisely since shadow-casting ones can have a large impact on performance.

Well, I just cut a long story short at this point: NoLimits 2 Roller Coaster Simulation has so many features I guess many users haven't discovered everything this program has to offer yet.

And if that wasn't enough already, the devs regularly provide the (very friendly and helpful) community with updates which will also eventually include new coaster styles and features in the future.


Soo ... what are you waiting for? Stop reading this review, get yourself a copy of NoLimits 2 and dive into the wonderful world of speed, height, thrill and fun. Btw, they say Oculus Rift enhances the experience even more.



[i]The total play time displayed here isn't correct as I've used the non-Steam version before, maybe add 100 hours and many more for NoLimits 1.[/i]

12755554.review:
No Limits 2 is hands-down the best roller coaster program I've used. It has a nearly endless seeming list of new features, most of which make things a whole lot easier than No Limits 1. There really is no competition. It's like comparing school cafeteria food to Olive Garden. It took 8 years but it was worth the wait.
I really like how much easier the building system is compared to NL1. That's one of my favorite things about NL2. That combined with auto-heartlining the track, I feel like I can build any sequence of curves how I want, in any shape. I don't really feel the need to look back or live in the past.
The graphics, while not a top priority for me, were made with TLC. The terrain editing, environments, and tree models pretty much encourage the user to make the most of it, particularly if they're designing a terrain coaster.
The combs, while not exact, give an indication of how I'm doing at making the ride survivable and smooth, and help take away more of the artificial difficulty that NL1 had. Having multiple viewports is slightly awkward but I can watch the G's of one viewport while watching the radii in the other. With this much in the way of new features to aid in smooth design, I feel like I can comfortably stick with hand-building, not even think about touching FVD++ (no offense Lenny). I really wanted to make smooth, heart-lined track and be able to easily adjust earlier portions at will if needed, and now I can.
The NL2MAT editor is pretty complicated for me, and I'm not sure if any adequate tutorials for that exist. Of course, scripting is even more complicated for me. I really like the scripting engine allows one to use custom trains. In fact, the attachment script is so versatile one can use it for custom trains, attaching headlights, automobiles, Tin Lizzies-type rides, Raging Rapids River Rides, etc. And this is just one little script. Too bad the scripting language is too complicated for most users.
As awesome as this program is, there are a few things I don't like.
-If I forget which park had a particular coaster I want to work on, I have to open and check each park. Search bar won't do.
-Testing the ride just in the editor seems to have been removed.
-G-force combs ignore dive machine holding brakes.
-Importing an element makes all the roll nodes 'strict' so I have to uncheck 'strict' on at least most of them. Might be a bug.
Overall I recommend this game for any roller coaster enthusiast, and anyone who wants to make virtual coasters but finds NL1 too hard. Even if you're not a die-hard fan and don't know the names of the manufacturers or if you don't ride roller coasters very often, I feel like the sequel difficulty drop may be enough that you just might enjoy it anyway to at least some extent.

I have always been interested in theme park simulation, like Roller Coaster Tycoon, Thrillville, Theme park etc...  But while they all focus on different aspect of theme parks (RCT is more about management, Thrillville is more game play oriented), none of theme focused exclusively on what I like the most: roller coasters.

With NoLimits 2, all that has changed.  Instead on focusing on multiple aspects of theme parks, NL2 is dedicated exclusively on roller coasters.  You build them, you ride them, and you share them. In fact, NL2 feels more like a development tools for roller coaster designers than a game simulation.

Building coasters in other applications was always a little awkward.  With NL2, building coaster is so easy almost everybody can built a coaster within minutes.  You still need to understand a few basics concept (like blocks for example) and understand how to use the tools.  But when you understand these fundamental concepts,  you will be able to build incredible coasters.  From there, your imagination is the only limit.  

The included documentation provides just enough to get you going.  If you want more information, some excellent tutorial videos are available on YouTube.

On a technical side, the application runs surprisingly well on laptops.  I had to set the resolution to 1280x720, but other than that, it works very well.  I can now build coaster when I am on the road.

I have yet to experiment with scripting and scenery so I cannot comment on these features.  But all in all, I am very satisfied with this application.  And the more I play, the more I find that while building a coaster is easy, building a GOOD coaster is hard and challenging. And when I see what other people do, I know that I have a long way to go before I could build a good coaster.

First off this is not a park management game like the RCT series. This is a simulator specifically for roller coasters. 

No limits 1 was the most successful rollercoaster simulator on the consumer market but 8 years ago was when the makers announced NoLimits 2. NoLimits 2 was out at the beginning of 2014 and I was just amazed at the detail and new features. This simulator has astonishing details and physics. Now for my review I'll start with the editor (I will compare with the original NoLimits 1). 

Editor: 
The editor in NoLimits 2 is really advanced and lets you do a lot more than NoLimits 1. First they introduced scripting which allows you to go beyond the limits of what's in the editor. But as with going with track placement, they are still doing the spline based track placement. But it has changed since NoLimits 1 as it's based off of vertexs and control polygons. The supports are the same as NoLimits 1 where it's just a single spline and node. One of my favorite features is the new import options, NoLimits 1 was stuck with .3ds formats but NoLimits 2 allows for Obj. formats which are far superior. the new editor also has a build in FVD tool and allows math formulas.

This is a great game to play if you are a roller coaster fan. I've played NoLimits since the first one came out and NoLimits 2 is just even better than the first!

11817207.review:
First off: this is not a game, if you're a fan of the Rollercoaster Tycoon games this might not be for you. It's a simulation and a tool made for people who may already have a wider knowlage of roller coasters. It has no park management features like Rollercoaster Tycoon. Nolimits often requires a quite in-depth understanding of rollercoaster engineering, physics and a passion for theme parks and roller coasters. If you're a Rollercoaster Tycoon player who wants to try something new, try the demo first.

Pros:
Realistic-This is the most realistic design tool for roller coasters. It's not just stunning in terms of visuals, it's full of tiny details that enthusiasts can all recognise and appreciate.

Massive improvement from NL1-Everything in the editor has been vastly improved, you could spend hours just fixing g-force spikes and bumps that aren't apparent in the editor. The G-force comb is nothing short of glorious, it allows you to fully finetune rides to perfection without the need for other software like Newton.

Improved terrain editor-The simple addition of tunnels make this many times better than NL1.

Verity-NL2 has more coaster types than you're likely to master. Classic corkscrew coasters to B&M diving coasters, this simulation has everything. I would have liked to see more family style coasters though.

Scripting-This is probably the biggest advance for NL2, it makes coaster extremely flexible, though it has some problems I'll mention later.

Station improvements-The addition of dueling stations and tandem stations is very helpful for creating realistic rides.

Control panel-In NL1 controlling the ride was pretty much pressing the f9-11 keys, now it's fully functional and allows you to control individual block segments. It's surprisingly fun to operate rides in the simulation, some people have even made their own physical USB control panels. Unfortunately for the people building their own controls, there is a lack of hotkeys for operation, all block controls must be controlled with the mouse (but this isn't much of a loss).

Cons: It’s important to be honest, there are some serious problems which aren't fixable but could potentially ruin your experience of NL2. 

No lessons learned from Newton-When people are forced to use other software for the actual design of a ride, there's a problem. The NL1 editor was very hard to use if you were building a coaster from scratch with no help from programs like Newton; NL2 has somewhat eliminated the need for Newton but a combination of Newton's perfectly smooth curve and the already amazing editor would have been beyond perfect.

Scripting-It's a gift wrapped with a lock and chains. If you have difficulty wrapping your head around scripting transfer tracks and switches, you're screwed. Like with Newton, the NL community has made some software to make scripting easier but it simply isn't enough. (What would have been perfect is a second scripting method based of placeable triggers, It would be less flexible but certainly easier to use).

And that's pretty much it.

Would I recommend NL2 to the average steam user? No.
Would I recommend NL2 to fan of Roller Coaster Tycoon fans? Maybe.
Would I recommend NL2 to roller coaster enthusiasts? Absolutely.

11813431.review:
No Limits Roller Coaster 2 is the ultimate roller coaster simulator in my own opinion! The editor features a built-in g-force calculator which is useful to shape the track correctly, and the track is easily smooth with the depump vertices tool. The simulator is really well done, the graphics are stunning and the rider view effect is very realistic. The possibilities are basically infinite!

One with skill could with some effort create their own Leviathan with the same high quality as the professionals. It however requires time and patience to create the perfect layout, but the result outcome is worth it. I've rode so many times the first roller coaster I've made because you feel like you are actually riding it! Creating supports is a little time consuming but you can actually save time by creating your own support prefabs.

Obviously, this software is considered as a game only for roller coaster lovers. Otherwise, you better play Roller Coaster Tycoon games if you prefer the money/human management.

11808965.review:
NoLimits 2 is such a fun community to be a part of! Rollercoaster enthusiasts have been waiting a long time until a proper rollercoaster game. NoLimits actually uses the same software that real rollercoaster engineers use to create their screaming behemoths. How cool is that!? 

That being said, the game does have a learning curve. It will take a while to master, buts it’s one of those games that’s well worth the time in trying to learn! Even though the game is billed as a rollercoaster simulator, you can even build whole theme parks! The easiest way being able to import your own .3ds models into the game. If you can't find any you like online or you are not good at creating them yourself, there are tutorials online in how to use the games supports system to create buildings and objects. Do not feel overwhelmed at first for there are tutorials all over to help get a handle on the program. 

It may take some time to create an amazing coaster/park, but seeing these engineering marvels standing tall over your beautiful landscape is well worth it. I recommend any rollercoaster enthusiast to try the game out!
